**US Manufacturing Sector Contracts Further in April Amid Tariff Pressures**
The US manufacturing sector contracted further in April, as tariffs on imported products continued to pressure supply chains, keeping input prices high. According to the Institute for Supply Management (ISM), the industrial PMI fell to 48.7 in the month, down from 49.0 in March. A PMI below 50 indicates contraction in the manufacturing sector, which accounts for 10.2% of the US economy. Economists surveyed by Reuters had predicted a PMI decline to 48. The survey covered the announcement of tariffs by President Donald Trump, which led to widespread tariffs on imports from US trade partners, including a 145% tariff on Chinese products, sparking a trade war with Beijing. The manufacturing industry relies heavily on imported raw materials. The second consecutive monthly decline in PMI ended a brief recovery in the industry, driven by hopes of a less stringent regulatory environment under the Trump administration and interest rate cuts by the Federal Reserve. There were no signs in the survey that factories continued to anticipate imports in the month, although the fear of higher prices due to tariffs may have led companies to anticipate orders. A surge in imports weighed on the Gross Domestic Product (GDP) in the first quarter. The sub-index of new prospective orders in the ISM survey improved to 47.2, after falling to 45.2 in March - the lowest reading since May 2023. Factory production remained depressed and supplier delivery performance worsened in the month. The supplier delivery index in the survey rose to 55.2 in April, from 53.5 in March. In this case, a reading above 50 indicates slower deliveries. With the slowdown in deliveries, the measure of the survey on prices paid by manufacturers for inputs rose to 69.8, the highest level since June 2022, from 69.4 in March, indicating a recovery in product prices, which had fallen in March. Factories continued to cut jobs, although the pace slowed. The employment measure in the industry survey rose to 46.5 from 44.7 in March.

**US Economy Already Sputtering Before Trade Pain Hit: Eco Week**
The US economy has been slowing down since the beginning of 2025, despite having a strong performance for most of last year. The main factors behind this slowdown are the increase in imports due to tariff policies, the expansion of trade deficits, and a decrease in consumer purchasing power. The Commerce Department is expected to release the 1-3 month (first quarter) GDP growth rate on April 30, which is predicted to be 0.4% year-over-year, a nearly 3-year low. **US Manufacturing Sector Contracts for First Time This Year Amid Trump Tariff Policy**
The US manufacturing sector contracted for the first time this year in March, with the ISM manufacturing index falling to 49.0, below the 50 threshold. This is a result of the Trump administration's tariff policy, which has increased uncertainty in the market. The ISM noted that despite the initial rebound in manufacturing at the beginning of the year, the tariff policy has severely impacted this trend. The data showed that the new orders index fell to 45.2, the lowest since May 2023, indicating a significant decrease in demand. As a result, production declined, leading to the first contraction in factory output this year. The employment index also fell to 44.7, a new low since September last year, indicating that companies are further reducing staff, reflecting the difficulties faced by the manufacturing sector. On the other hand, the factory materials price index rose to 69.4, up 7 points from February, a new high since June 2022, indicating that material prices are rising and that inflationary pressures may continue to rise, pushing overall price levels higher. As companies accelerate imports to avoid upcoming tariffs, the ISM's import index has declined, showing that companies' demand for foreign goods has begun to stabilize. The supplier delivery index also fell from 54.5 in February to 53.5, indicating a slight slowdown in delivery speeds. This change reflects the reduction in imports due to tariff uncertainty and the risk of supply chain disruptions. As the tariff policy intensifies, economists have become increasingly pessimistic about the US economy's future growth prospects. Goldman Sachs economists have adjusted their recession probability, predicting a 35% chance of recession in the next 12 months, up from 20% previously. The sudden decline in business and consumer confidence has made the market even more anxious about the future economic outlook. The Federal Reserve has paused interest rate cuts in January and is closely monitoring the impact of the tariff policy on economic activity. Although some industries, such as oil, coal, and metal manufacturing, have shown growth, the overall manufacturing sector is facing double pressure from domestic and foreign uncertainty. Companies' delay in investment plans, supply chain disruptions, and the cost increase brought by tariffs may further drag down the US manufacturing recovery.

**US Industrial Production Index Falls Below Growth Threshold**
The US Industrial Production Index, as measured by the Institute for Supply Management (ISM), fell to 49.0 points in March, a 1.3 point decrease from the previous month. This is a stronger decline than expected, with economists forecasting a drop to 49.5 points. The ISM Index has fallen below the growth threshold of 50 points, indicating a contraction in economic activity. According to Ulrich Wortberg, economist at Landesbank Hessen-Thüringen, 'The volatile US policy, which has introduced and increased tariffs on many trading partners, is likely to blame for the decline.' Wortberg also notes that growth concerns are increasing, but it is uncertain whether the US Federal Reserve will feel pressured to loosen monetary policy quickly, given the risks of inflation. The sub-indicators for new orders and employment both fell below the growth threshold, while the prices paid index rose significantly, reaching its highest level since June 2022.

**US Industrial Activity Expands in January for First Time in Over Two Years**
The US industrial activity grew for the first time in over two years in January, due to strong order numbers, but a measure of the prices paid by factories for raw materials increased, and higher ones are likely after President Donald Trump imposed tariffs on Canadian and Mexican products over the weekend. The Institute for Supply Management (ISM) reported that its manufacturing PMI rose to 50.9 last month, the highest reading since September 2022, from 49.2 in December. This was the first time since October 2022 that the PMI rose above the 50 mark, indicating growth in the manufacturing sector, which accounts for 10.3% of the economy. Economists consulted by Reuters had predicted a PMI of 49.8. The recovery, likely driven in part by hopes of tax cuts, may be short-lived, as tariffs are expected to increase raw material costs and disrupt supply chains. Trump imposed tariffs of 25% on Canadian and Mexican products, which are set to take effect on Tuesday. Manufacturing was hurt by the Federal Reserve's decision to raise interest rates in 2022 and 2023 to control inflation. The US central bank began its cycle of monetary easing in September, reducing rates by 100 basis points before pausing in January due to uncertainty over the economic impact of government policies. The ISM's new orders subindex jumped from 52.1 in December to 55.1 last month. Factory production also increased. The price measure paid by manufacturers reached an eight-month high of 54.9, from 52.5 in December. Imports grew, suggesting that manufacturers were stocking up on materials before the tariffs. Factory employment expanded for the first time since May, with the employment index in the sector recovering to 50.3, compared to 45.4 in December, according to ISM's Tom Moeller, who said, 'The employment index is a good indicator of the overall health of the manufacturing sector.'

Source:[Terra](https://www.terra.com.br/economia/atividade-industrial-dos-eua-se-expande-em-janeiro-pela-1-vez-desde-2022-mostra-ism,1c58febc148ced4bb454598688ec8841cvg20g65.html)
summary:
Experts are divided, but the consensus slightly favors a positive year-over-year growth for US industrial production in May 2025, though with substantial downside risk. All experts note that April 2025 saw +1.49% YoY growth, driven primarily by an energy sector (oil extraction/processing) surge and a calendar effect (an extra working day). Most are skeptical that these boosts will repeat in May; several expect the calendar tailwind to vanish and oil output to plateau or pull back.

Key negative factors cited include contractionary manufacturing indices (ISM, regional Fed surveys), deteriorating global manufacturing (especially in China and South Korea), ongoing or intensifying tariff/trade disruptions, and sector-wide weakness outside of energy and select tech. Regional and sectoral analyses emphasize that broad-based US manufacturing is in contraction, and that risks of a dip to 0% or negative YoY growth—though still modest by historical base rates—are elevated by policy headwinds and soft demand.

On the positive side, several forecasters highlight resilience in energy, emerging tech sectors (AI, electronics), strong equity markets, and a still-solid labor market, which could cushion the industrial downturn or keep the YoY print just positive by inertia or base effects.

Probabilities provided by experts range from 35% to 75% for a positive YoY outcome in May, with most in the 58–75% band, a few (especially regional and IO-focused) seeing sub-40% odds. Scenarios for a No outcome generally require both the energy sector to falter and negative manufacturing trends to fully translate into hard output data. Yes scenarios assume ongoing strength or only modest retrace in energy/tech, and sufficient economic momentum to offset sectoral and policy weakness.

Summing up, most forecasters expect a narrow positive YoY print for May 2025, albeit with substantial risk of a zero or slightly negative outcome if the April gains prove flukes. The median probability estimate lies around 60–65%, reflecting a cautious but modestly optimistic consensus.
